item.title: Listening to Omar Thomas – Come Sunday II. Shout!
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: On the Academic Music Discord server, someone posted a video about Omar Thomas, a composer I had never…
item.content:encoded:
On the Academic Music Discord server, someone posted a video about Omar Thomas, a composer I had never heard of before.

A composer, arranger and educator, Omar Thomas was born in Brooklyn, N.Y., in 1984. His parents are Guyanese, and he moved to Boston in 2006 to pursue a Master of Music degree at New England Conservatory.

A piece written for a wind ensemble, Piano and Drum Set, Come Sunday celebrates the Hammond organ’s central role in black worship. The second movement, Shout!, is an energetic celebration of gospel, jazz and blues, which shows influences from Duke Wellington and Charles Mingus as well as traditional church singing.

In listening to Shout!, I was surprised at how energetic it was after the slow and melodic first movement. There was an instant connection for me to the rhythm of this piece, marked by brass, bass, and drums, with the repetitive woodwinds in a high register adding the necessary tension.

As I listened to this piece, I was reminded of 70s funk horns and woodwinds. That’s what makes this piece so beautiful. Mixing genres and decades, creating a fresh and joyful time for the listener and for the players.

Since I am unfamiliar with much of the new classical music, I am enjoying this opportunity to listen to contemporary composers. At the same time that I study traditional techniques, I believe this will facilitate me in understanding the paths new composers are taking.

item.title: Listening to Tan Dun, Eldbjørg Hemsing – Violin Concerto “Rhapsody & Fantasia”: Ia. Rock the Violin in Rhapsody. Hip-Hop
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: In another Spotify discovery, I listened to a piece that I had never heard before. My attention was…
item.content:encoded:
In another Spotify discovery, I listened to a piece that I had never heard before. My attention was immediately captured when a traditional drum kit entered playing a classic hip-hop pattern in the first 16 seconds.

Rock the Violin in Rhapsody. Hip-Hop is the first movement of the Violin Concerto “Rhapsody & Fantasy” by Eldbjørg Hemsing and Tan Dun. Hemsing is one of the best violinists in Norway, while Tan Dun is one of the most renowned conductors and composers that lives in New York but was born in China.

Having found a score for this concerto, I discovered that it includes a strong percussion section with five players, in addition to woodwinds, brass, and strings. It’s easy to hear the rhythm throughout this piece since it’s very heavy on it.

My favourite aspect of the piece was the constant play between rhythmic, hip-hop ambient and the almost wild solo violin. The play kept the piece alive and prevented it from becoming monotonous, which could happen with a simple hip-hop beat.

As described by Xenia Hanusiak in her article, the composer calls this Rhapsody and Fantasia “the perfect result” of his thirty-five years of living in New York. It is one of the most interesting pieces I have heard in a while due to its combination of street sound rhythm, classical Chinese instruments, and a harsh nordic violin.

item.title: Listening to Max Bruch – Concerto for Clarinet & Viola, Op. 88: I. Andante Con Moto
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Max Bruch (1838-1920) is a well-known prolific German composer. During his long career, he taught, conducted, and composed.…
item.content:encoded:
Max Bruch (1838-1920) is a well-known prolific German composer. During his long career, he taught, conducted, and composed. In 1911, Bruch composed the Double Concerto in E minor, Op.88. This piece was composed for his son Max Felix Bruch, who was a first-class clarinettist.

A review of Bruch’s Double Concerto Op.88 premiere, published in Allgemeine Musikzeitung Zeitung No. 40 (1913), called it “harmless,” “weak,” and “uninteresting” (Fifield, 1988).

Initially, I was intrigued by the strange combination of clarinet and viola in this Double Concerto. My impression after listening to this piece is that both instruments can very well mimic human timbres. As a result, the solo instruments have a lyrical and melodic sound. As the two solo instruments weave melodies around each other, the orchestra provides a stable backdrop.

The first movement of this work presents Bruch’s two solo instruments in a rather dramatic manner. In the beginning, the solo viola is boldly introduced, followed by the clarinet. Throughout the entire movement, it feels as if both instruments are having an intimate conversation.

Upon hearing this movement, I felt as if there was nothing shocking and nothing wrong, at least to my ears. In addition to being a conservative, Bruch was opposed to ‘modern madness’ and ‘modernists’ like Strauss, Reger, and Debussy (the latter he termed an ‘unqualified scribbler’). As a whole, I enjoyed this piece, especially the interplay between the two solo instruments.

References

Fifield, C. (1988) Max Bruch his life and works. London: Gollancz.

Viola and clarinet concerto and other viola compositions by Bruch (no date) Viola in Music.com. Available at: http://www.viola-in-music.com/viola-and-clarinet-concerto.html .

item.title: Listening to Masses
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: During my research, I listened to masses from different periods of history, but my focus was exclusively on…
item.content:encoded:
During my research, I listened to masses from different periods of history, but my focus was exclusively on the Kyrie.

Machaut: Messe de Nostra Dame: Kyrie (1365)
(Guillaume & Royllart, 2016)

This Ordinary of the Mass composed before 1365 is considered the earliest complete setting attributable to any single composer. The Kyrie is written in polyphony for four voices and features lots of melismas. This piece is divided into three sections, each with the same structure: polyphony – plainchant – polyphony. As far as the sound quality is concerned, I found it to be very diverse, with each voice having its own distinct characteristics, but working together to create a pleasing whole.

Victoria: Missa O magnum mysterium: Kyrie (1592)
(Smith & de, 1997)

O magnum mysterium (published in 1572) became the basis for Victoria’s 1592 Mass for a four-part choir. Since this short Kyrie is in imitation polyphonic texture, the voices do not appear to have any real distinctive characteristic, but rather blend together to achieve a more common sound.

Bach: Mass in B minor: Kyrie I (1749)
(Herreweghe, 2011)

Compared to my previous two masses, this is a big difference. This work is for five voices with instrumental accompaniment, which makes a completely different sound from choral masses without accompaniment. It is evident that Bach is stepping up the masses from church music to concert music, making them suitable for a concert hall. In this polyphonic Kyrie, what I found most interesting is the way, from bar 30, the sound never settles until the last bar. The tension and expectation lasts for about 5 minutes.

Mozart: Great Mass in C minor K.427: Kyrie (1783)
(Bernstein et al., 1991)

After listening to it, I understand why it is considered one of Mozart’s greatest works. It is a magnificent composition for two soprano soloists, a tenor and a bass, a double chorus and a large orchestra. Similarly to Bach’s mass, Mozart wanted to make the experience more performance and entertainment-based, instead of contemplative and solemn. For me, the most appealing part of this Kyrie is the soprano solo, particularly when it reaches a low Ab and jumps two octaves higher in the following measure.

Beethoven: Mass in C Major, Op.86:I. Kyrie (1807)
(Kampen, K.V. et al., 2005)

Compared to the previous masses I had listened to, the texture of this Kyrie surprised me. In my opinion, Beethoven decided to compose a homophonic-based mass that heavily relied on the choir. Throughout, there is an intriguing play of dynamics, swaying up and down and conveying different emotions in a short space of time, with some parts with breathtaking soaring voices. A note about Gloria in excelsis Deo, which is one of my favourite versions I’ve heard.

Bruckner: Mass in E minor: Kyrie (1866)
(Parkman, 2019)

It’s a mass that feels like a travel back in time, stripped of all instrumental accompaniment and focusing primarily on choral. The combination of choir and brass in this Kyrie really caught my attention. This created a very dramatic and mournful sound. But I was most impressed by the use of silences and the absence of sound in some parts, which gave this piece a huge hollowness.

References

Guillaume and Royllart, P. (2016) Machaut, G. de: Messe de nostre dame (diabolus in Musica, guerber), Youtube. Available at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lOVsY1rxJB8.

Smith, S. and de, V.T.L. (1997) Victoria, T.L. de: Vocal music (tenebrae responsories) (ensemble Corund, S. Smith), Youtube. Naxos Digital Services US Inc. Available at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NGyWrtWgHjA.

Herreweghe, P. (2011) Mass in B minor BWV 232 ; Collegium Vocale Gent ; Philippe Herreweghe, Youtube. Harmonia mundi. Available at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zS2biN257sQ.

Bernstein, L. et al. (1991) Große Messe C-Moll K 427 (417a): Version: Franz Beyer = great mass in C minor = Grande Messe en ut mineur, Youtube. Available at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GUtLXacCT5M.

Kampen, K.V. et al. (2005) Messe C-Dur = Mass in C major = Messe en UT majeur: Op. 86, Spotify. Hänssler Classic. Available at: https://open.spotify.com/track/2k7AQGyLChW5JlcWhvBwLc?si=39803a01a70f4435.

item.title: Listening to José Almarcha – Casa del Gallego
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: As usual, my Spotify is on shuffle and today I heard some flamenco, which I am not particularly…
item.content:encoded:
As usual, my Spotify is on shuffle and today I heard some flamenco, which I am not particularly familiar with, but enjoy listening to occasionally. This song caught my attention, so I listened carefully.

Originally from Ciudad Real, José Almarcha is an outstanding guitarist and composer. As a student of flamenco at the Córdoba Conservatory of Music, José studied with flamenco masters including Paco Serrano and Niño de Pura. A number of dancers have been accompanied by him, including Olga Pericet, Marco Flores, and Antonio Canales. His albums have received excellent reviews and he has been hailed as one of Spain’s most promising flamenco guitarists.

The singer recently released Casa del Gallego, which is a farruca, a dance-centric style of flamenco characterized by sombre virtuosity, aggressive footwork, and dramatic tempo changes. 

In this song, the melody is introduced by a flamenco guitar riff, but a few seconds into the song, there’s a surprise: a trombone with a delay effect. Not a typical flamenco sound and a hint to the listener that this probably isn’t a traditional flamenco but yes, a modern view of the style.

Enters the piano a few seconds later. With the trombone on the bottom, the piano on top with high notes, and the flamenco guitar in the middle, the three instruments make a beautiful sonic sandwich.

A mellow melody is gradually introduced by the trio, along with occasional cymbal sounds. Still, the strumming and tapping of guitars always have a slight tension to them. Suddenly, the tension is released as the full band enters, with a Latin rhythm recognizable as flamenco, accompanied by a shoe-tapping sound, along with another surprise: an electric guitar. There is a clash between traditional and modern sounds in the music now, and I find it very appealing.

As the song continues, tension is built and released with more and more shoe tapping and stomping until the apotheosis.

It was very interesting to see how flamenco is approached in a new way. It was entertaining to watch the piece’s sudden changes in sound dynamics that are intended to be interpreted by a dancer and add drama to the performance.

item.title: Research point 1.0 – Renaissance madrigals
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: Claudio Monteverdi (1567–1643) Monteverdi was an Italian composer, violinist, singer, and priest. He is often considered a revolutionary…
item.content:encoded:
Claudio Monteverdi (1567–1643)

Monteverdi was an Italian composer, violinist, singer, and priest. He is often considered a revolutionary who marked the transition from Renaissance to Baroque music.

Until the age of forty, Monteverdi worked primarily on madrigals, composing a total of nine books. In about four years, Monteverdi completed his first book of twenty-one madrigals for five voices. Overall, the first eight madrigals show the massive development from Renaissance polyphonic to baroque monodic styles.

He wrote L’Orfeo, one of the earliest operas in the history of music, an innovative work that remains a part of today’s orchestra’s repertoire. Additionally, he has written sacred music.

Orlando di Lasso (1532 – 1594)

Lasso was a Franco-Flemish composer. With more than two thousand compositions to his credit, he was a prolific and versatile author. This collection includes all genres of his day, secular and sacred, including the mass, secular chanson in several languages, Latin motets, hymns, and madrigals. When he held the position of Kapellmeister at the Munich court, at the end of his life, he cultivated sacred music with a special dedication.

He is considered the chief representative of the mature polyphonic style of the Netherlands school, along with Giovanni Pierluigi da Palestrina. At the end of the 16th century, he was one of the most famous and influential musicians in Europe.

Regarding his madrigals, which he penned while living in Rome, his style was clear and concise, and his tunes were memorable.

Comparison between Orlando di Lasso’s Matona, mia cara and Claudio Monteverdi’s Ah, Dolente Partita

The main reason I chose to compare these two madrigals is their contrasting themes. Lasso’s one is a jovial, lighthearted, and almost mocking monologue between a German soldier and a supposedly Italian woman. Contrary to Monteverdi, his lament is a sombre recognition of death in late life.

From the very beginning, these contrasting themes are evident. Matona, mia cara begins with all four voices in an F Major chord and in a fast tempo. The song develops with a mostly homophonic texture and a very marked rhythm, especially in the “Don, don, don” section. 

Ah, Dolente partita opens with only two voices in unison, singing a long, high E. The two voices stay in unison until bar 4 when they drift apart. As a result, it sounds very sorrowful and enigmatic. As the other voices enter, they do so timidly and not simultaneously. Only in bar 15 do all five voices sing together. However, just after that, in bar 16, the top two voices become silent. This creates a variety of aural experiences that convey the theme of lamentation.

Monteverdi’s madrigal has a more polyphonic texture than Lasso’s. Consequently, Ah, Dolente partita has a richer sound ambience, but Matona, mia cara has a stronger rhythmic mark. 

As a final contrast, I would like to mention the melodic shape. In Lasso’s madrigal, there are some upward and downward lines, with a lot of repetition of the melody, so it could be sung in a group with a dance-like feeling. Monteverdi’s melody, however, tends to move downward or remain flat, which is most evident towards the end, as if the music is taking small steps toward death.

References

Arnold, Denis Midgley. “Claudio Monteverdi”. Encyclopedia Britannica, 28 Mar. 2022, https://www.britannica.com/biography/Claudio-Monteverdi. Accessed 16 September 2022.

Britannica, The Editors of Encyclopaedia. “Orlando di Lasso”. Encyclopedia Britannica, 10 Jun. 2022, https://www.britannica.com/biography/Orlando-di-Lasso. Accessed 16 September 2022.

MORTENSEN, B., 2009. Recording Reviews – [Claudio Monteverdi: Madrigals]: “Flaming Heart”; “Fire and Ashes”. Choral Journal, 50(5), pp. 60-61. Accessed 16 September 2022.

fhunrichse, 2008. King’s Singers – Madrigal History Tour – Matona mia cara, YouTube. Available at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TPlb2jKCCQI . Accessed September 16, 2022.

item.title: Listening to Oscar Peterson – Hymn To Freedom
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: I came across Oscar Peterson through a Mic.com article called “Did Jazz Forget About Oscar Petterson?”. The author points…
item.content:encoded:
I came across Oscar Peterson through a Mic.com article called “Did Jazz Forget About Oscar Petterson?”. The author points out that when you think about jazz names, Petterson’s is not the first that comes to your mind (Johnson, 2022).

Until today, I was unaware of Oscar Peterson’s name or work. Therefore, I decided to listen to “Hymn To Freedom”, a song featured in the article.

Oscar Peterson was born in Montreal, Canada on August 15, 1925 and grew up in a family where music was required of all five children. At the age of seven, he was able to play trumpet and piano. In his teens, he was already a prodigy when he became the star attraction of Canada’s renowned big band, the Johnny Holmes Orchestra (Peterson, 2003), and he was just 20 years old when he made his first trio recordings for RCA.

As a result of his musical genius, he was able to play with and alongside many jazz legends of the era, including Ella Fitzgerald, Roy Eldridge, Louis Armstrong, Charlie Parker, and Billie Holiday (Johnson, 2022).

From 1959-1965, he formed and played with the Oscar Peterson trio with Ray Brown on bass and Ed Thigpen on drums, becoming one of jazz history’s most celebrated groups. Jazz historian Alyn Shipton explains one of their strengths as “Peterson’s skill at promoting group interaction marked the beginning of a seismic shift in piano trios.” (Hansen, 2014).

During the 1960s, there was racial segregation throughout the United States and Canada, and Peterson suffered a lot of racism when he toured with the Oscar Peterson trio. However, the experience of touring all over the world and especially his experiences in the south of the United States and observing the approach Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. took to peaceful protest, led him to write his most influential work, the “Hymn to Freedom” (Small, 2021).

People all over the world quickly embraced “Hymn To Freedom” as the anthem of the Civil Rights Movement when it was written in 1962. A timeless and relevant piece, this song has been played at many major events around the globe.

This song’s main melody captured my attention from the first listen. The song reminded me of a gospel song infused with blues and jazz. 

In terms of structure, Peterson plays the melody four times before going into his solo, then returning to the original melody one last time. I believe this is an effective way of structuring a hymn, since the first four times he repeats the melody with almost no variation. As a result, the listener is able to engage with the melodic intention of the song. The piano solo builds upon the previous chord progression, but it is melodically much more unique than those first four repetitions, creating some interest. He concludes the solo with an apotheosis, but then the original melody is played softer, calmer, bringing peace to the listener’s heart.

My favorite part of this melody is the contrary motion technique, in which both voices go in opposite directions. While I’m still trying to figure out why I find it so pleasing to hear, I think it’s because it constantly creates a broader range of sounds. This makes it bigger and more interesting as a way of moving to the next part.

References

Johnson, M., 2022. DID JAZZ FORGET ABOUT OSCAR PETERSON?. [online] Mic.Com. Available at: https://www.mic.com/culture/oscar-peterson-black-white [Accessed September 15, 2022].

Hansen, F.A., 2014, The arrangement qualities and musical style of the Oscar Peterson Trio: 1959–1965, Five Towns College [Accessed September 15, 2022].

Peterson, O., 2003, “A Jazz Odyssey: The Life of Oscar Peterson”, Jazz Education Journal, vol. 35, no. 4, pp. C2-C4, C7 [Accessed September 15, 2022].

Small, C., 2021. The Black + White Truth about Oscar Peterson and racism in Canada. POV Magazine. Available at: https://povmagazine.com/the-black-white-truth-about-oscar-peterson-and-racism-in-canada/ [Accessed September 15, 2022].

item.title: Listening to Gesualdo
item.dc:creator: Pedro
item.description: I must admit that I didn’t know who Gesualdo was until today, so I had to make some…
item.content:encoded:
I must admit that I didn’t know who Gesualdo was until today, so I had to make some research about the composer.

A Prince who composed secular madrigals, sacred vocal music, and instrumental music, Carlo Gesualdo da Venosa (c 1566 – 1613) published six books of madrigals and three books of sacred pieces during his lifetime. He was also notorious for brutally murdering his wife and lover in bed. In addition to this cold-hearted murder, many depraved tales have been told about Gesualdo’s mental health. Through these stories (whether true or not, it’s up for debate), we can trace a psychological portrait behind the composer whose work represents the culmination of Renaissance music at the end of the 16th century.

His harmonic language is still considered daring and extravagant today because it incorporates elements of the late Italian madrigals, characterized by sound experimentalism. He used complex chromaticism in a way that was extraordinary for his time. This would not be heard again, or even hinted at until Wagner, Schoenberg and Stravinsky took it to new heights.

This idiosyncratic use of chromaticism was not only an attempt to break the rules, representing his era in which Mannerism was emerging as deliberately disruptive but also had a rather specific objective: word painting.

As an example, when the subject of Amor, pace non chero of his 1st Book of Madrigals calls for his lover, he uses consonance and long notes (Garbuio & Fiorini, 2015).

But in Mille volte il moro of his 6th Book of Madrigals, the Morte (death) is described with uncontrolled polyphony and highly dissonant intervals (Garbuio & Fiorini, 2015).

It’s interesting to see how the technical complexity and themes changed from one book to another during his short life. The polyphonic tradition of the Renaissance dominates the first two books, while harmonic experimentalism dominates the third and fourth books. The last two, however, are characterized by more chromatic and dissonant writing, typically associated with mature composers. Considering the themes, his first two books are more simplistic, whereas his last two books are more dramatic in depicting themes of torture, pain, sadness, and death.

It surprised me to find that although we see Gesualdo as an avant-garde musical genius of his time, some people consider him conservative.

“As conservative as it was possible to be in this time. Monteverdi was the radical, the new. There is a very curious letter from the poet Guarini, in which he says he prefers Gesualdo to the modern style because he is ‘so far from the hardness of Monteverdi.’ For Guarini, Gesualdo is so nice, so easy! Exactly the opposite of what we now think.”

(Ross, 2011)

Even though other contemporary composers experimented with new sonorities and pushed further the boundaries of what music could be, I believe Gesualdo was one of the leading composers of the late Renaissance. While developing polyphony, a better sense of structure and rhythmic order, he explored contrasting emotions (like in Dolcissima mia vita) and influenced composers hundreds of years after his death.

References

Ross, A., 2011. Gesualdo. Alex Ross: The Rest Is Noise. Available at: https://www.therestisnoise.com/2011/12/gesualdo.html [Accessed September 14, 2022].

Burton-Hill, C., 2014. Gesualdo: Glorious music and grisly murder. BBC Culture. Available at: https://www.bbc.com/culture/article/20130905-a-16th-century-musical-badass [Accessed September 14, 2022].

Garbuio, R.L. & Fiorini, C.F., 2015. “amor” e “morte” Nos Madrigais de Carlo Gesualdo: Um estudo sobre o desenvolvimento da escrita musical e textual. Per Musi. Available at: https://www.scielo.br/j/pm/a/rfCGr7VrcVTbmsczxX8YTsn/ [Accessed September 14, 2022].
